There's no point in trade that exchanges goods that cost the same as you produce locally. You have to get them cheaper than you would have or there wouldn't be a benefit to it. Follow that logic and there has to be an imbalance UNLESS you hit the extremely improbable outcome that by chance there are exactly as many wins on either side for a particular country. It's inherently unlikely though because countries are inherently different to each other. What you need is an overall trade balance across all countries so you aren't going into debt. But insisting on getting that a per country level is going to essentially constrain you to low value trade in most places.

Comment: Having a trade deficit with China isn't a real problem. There are some real problems that are sort of adjacent to it, though, and they don't really have easy fixes (they're also all, by the way, made way fucking worse by these tariffs).   One problem is that China is doing a bunch of unethical shit like using child labor as well as enslaving and genociding Uyghurs. I don't know how to solve that problem. Realistically, it requires a lot of governments that care about their poor and working class more than they do for their billionaires to work together to reduce wealth inequality globally, and I've got no fucking clue how to make that happen.   Another issue *is* the reduction in American domestic manufacturing capability. We still assemble a lot of stuff and have some heavy industry, but heavy industry is declining. There are a lot of causes for this, and it's impossible for me to give a comprehensive explanation of why in a reddit post. It's not really important economically to have domestic production if you can close the economic gap with services (which we've done quite well for a very long time), but it is potentially a very serious national security issue if we ever end up in a war with a peer adversary.   Part of the cause is that the US dollar is still the world's reserve currency (although it's questionable how long that continues to be the case). That inflates the value of the dollar, making it really cheap for Americans to travel overseas and buy stuff overseas, but it makes it relatively more expensive to pay Americans to do things. To be clear, I think it is more to the benefit of the United States than its detriment to be in that very powerful global economic position. I also think it does, however, necessitate a different style of government subsidization of industry to what we've seen previously (and that money would have to come from the ultra wealthy. Tax wealth, not work.)
